title: 106_hr5584
content: The "Educational Empowerment Act" designates Educational Empowerment Zones under a new subchapter in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Educational Empowerment Act" establishes educational empowerment zones as designated areas by the Secretaries of Health and Human Services and Education, with a limit of 30 zones. The "Educational Empowerment Act" allows for up to 30 nominated areas to be designated as educational empowerment zones based on specific criteria, with regulations to be published by the Secretaries of Health and Human Services and Education. The Secretaries concerned will prescribe regulations within 4 months of enactment for nominating educational empowerment zones based on size, population characteristics, and evaluation criteria. Designation of zones can only occur within a 24-month period following the regulations. The Secretaries concerned must follow procedural rules for designating nominated areas as educational empowerment zones, including submission of nominations in the required manner and accuracy of information provided. Additionally, a nomination process for Indian reservations is outlined. The nomination process for Indian reservations under the educational empowerment zone program involves the reservation governing body being treated as both the State and local governments for the nominated area. Designations remain in effect until December 31, 2005, or until revoked by the Secretaries concerned. The Secretary of Commerce has the authority to designate areas and determine eligibility requirements. The Secretary of Commerce may designate a nominated area as an educational empowerment zone if it meets specific requirements related to the area's location and boundaries. The Secretary of Education sets eligibility requirements for nominated areas to be designated as educational empowerment zones, considering factors like low-income families, high dropout rates, teen pregnancy, and large class sizes. Coordination with enterprise communities is required if an area holds both designations. The text discusses the designation of areas as educational empowerment zones and enterprise communities, with coordination required for areas holding both designations. Definitions and special rules apply for these designations. SEC. 30B. CONTRIBUTIONS TO SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN EDUCATIONAL EMPOWERMENT ZONES. Taxpayers can receive a credit against their tax for qualified educational empowerment zone contributions made during the taxable year. The maximum credit is $2,000 for individuals and $10,000 for other taxpayers. Qualified contributions are cash donations to school districts in designated educational empowerment zones. Taxpayers can receive a credit for qualified educational empowerment zone contributions made during the taxable year. The credit is limited to $2,000 for individuals and $10,000 for other taxpayers. Qualified contributions are cash donations to school districts in designated educational empowerment zones. The deduction under section 170 is allowed for hiring new teachers, increasing teacher salaries, and training teachers. No double benefit deduction is allowed. Taxpayers must elect to apply this section for a taxable year. The credit cannot exceed the regular tax reduced by other credits. The tax credit for qualified educational empowerment zone contributions is limited to $2,000 for individuals and $10,000 for other taxpayers. Excess credits can be carried over to the following taxable year. The tax credit for contributions to school districts in educational empowerment zones is limited to $2,000 for individuals and $10,000 for other taxpayers. Excess credits can be carried over to the following taxable year. The Teacher Loan Forgiveness Program under the Higher Education Act of 1965 includes loan forgiveness for mathematics and science teachers. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. The purpose of this section is to encourage individuals to enter and remain in teaching mathematics, science, and related fields. The Secretary will repay loans for new borrowers who have worked as full-time teachers for 3 years in an educational empowerment zone and are fully qualified teachers. Loan repayment under the Revenue Code of 1986 is available to fully qualified teachers who are not in default on a loan. Repayment is on a first-come, first-served basis, with priority given to those who received repayment in the previous fiscal year. The Secretary has the authority to create necessary regulations for this program. Loan repayment under the Revenue Code of 1986 is available to fully qualified teachers who are not in default on a loan. The Secretary may repay up to 80% of the outstanding principal amounts of qualifying loans after 3 years of service, with additional increments over the next 2 years, not exceeding a total of $10,000. No refunding of repayments is allowed, and interest may apply to the repaid portion of the loan. The Secretary repays a portion of a loan under specific conditions, including interest repayment. Borrowers cannot receive double benefits for the same service. The Secretary pays eligible lenders the aggregate amount of loans subject to repayment. Eligible individuals must apply for repayment. Each eligible individual must submit a complete application to the Secretary for loan repayment under specific conditions after completing the required years of qualifying employment. Applicants must demonstrate State certification as a teacher if teaching in a public elementary or secondary school. To qualify for loan repayment, eligible individuals must hold a teaching certification or pass the State teacher licensing exam. For elementary school teachers, a bachelor's degree and proficiency in various subjects are required. For middle or secondary school teachers, a bachelor's degree and high competency in all subjects taught are necessary. The program requires individuals to demonstrate high performance on academic tests or completion of an academic major in the subject areas they teach. The Secretary will conduct a national evaluation of the program's impact on a competitive basis to determine the number of individuals encouraged by the program. The program aims to encourage individuals to pursue teaching careers in mathematics, science, or related fields. The evaluation will determine the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness, and duration of participation in the program. The Secretary will submit interim reports to the President and Congress as deemed appropriate. The Secretary will submit a final report on the evaluation of the program by January 1, 2004.
